importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the announcement of the expulsions, marking a significant development in China’s anti-corruption campaign and political restructuring.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The campaign against corruption in the People’s Liberation Army began in 2023, setting the context for the removal of senior military officials in 2025.

keyTakeAways: Two top Chinese military leaders, He Weidong and Miao Hua, have been expelled from the Communist Party and the People’s Liberation Army on corruption charges.

He Weidong, China’s number two general and former vice-chairman of the Central Military Commission, is the first sitting general on the Central Military Commission to be expelled since the 1966–1976 Cultural Revolution.

The purge includes seven other senior military officials, including former Eastern Theatre Command commander Lin Xiangyang, former political commissars of the Army and Navy, and Wang Xiubin of the Joint Operations Command Centre.

The expulsions are part of President Xi Jinping’s broader anti-corruption drive, signaling a shift in military leadership and potential appointments at the Central Military Commission and Central Committee Plenum.

He Weidong has close ties to President Xi Jinping, dating back to their time in Fujian and Zhejiang provinces in the late 1990s, and played a key role in planning live-fire drills around Taiwan in 2022.
The removals are expected to be formalized at the upcoming Fourth Plenum of the Central Committee in Beijing, which will finalize key personnel decisions.
The expulsions are considered a significant achievement in China’s military anti-corruption campaign and suggest a tightening of control within the military leadership structure.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Two top Chinese military officials, He Weidong and Miao Hua, have been expelled from the Communist Party and the People’s Liberation Army on corruption charges, marking the most senior military officers to be purged in an anti-corruption campaign that began in 2023. He Weidong, a former vice-chairman of the Central Military Commission and close ally of President Xi Jinping, is the first sitting general to be expelled from the CMC since the Cultural Revolution. The purge is part of a broader effort by President Xi to restructure military leadership and eliminate corruption, with implications for China’s military strategy and regional security—particularly in cross-strait relations. The expulsions are expected to be formalized at the upcoming Central Committee Fourth Plenum, where new appointments may be made. He Weidong’s ties to Xi Jinping date back to their time in Fujian and Zhejiang provinces, and he played a key role in planning military drills around Taiwan after Nancy Pelosi's visit in 2022. The actions underscore a shift in China’s internal power dynamics and reinforce President Xi’s central authority over military and political affairs.
title: China expels two top generals from Communist Party in anti-corruption crackdown
